publicwhip.spmotion: *S3M-7837 Bob Doris: A Tribute to Donovan—That the Parliament congratulates Maryhill-born Donovan, considered a legendary folk-pop troubadour, on winning the BBC Radio 2 Lifetime Achievement Award; considers remarkable his career as an itinerant folk musician, creating acoustic hits in 1965 with Catch the Wind and Colours and his version of Buffy Sainte-Marie’s protest anthem, Universal Soldier; notes that he worked with the Beatles, and understands that he influenced Paul McCartney, John Lennon and George Harrison in their guitar styles and that, in his enduring career, he has played with folk music greats including Pete Seeger, Joan Baez and Bob Dylan.
S3M-7837 A Tribute to Donovan (lodged on 1 February 2011) Jamie Hepburn*

S3M-7837 A Tribute to Donovan (lodged on 1 February 2011) Brian Adam*, Hugh O’Donnell*, Ken Macintosh*, Stuart McMillan*, Linda Fabiani*, Bill Kidd*, Rob Gibson*, Mike Pringle*, Gil Paterson*, Robin Harper*

S3M-7837 Bob Doris: A Tribute to Donovan—That the Parliament congratulates Maryhill-born Donovan, considered a legendary folk-pop troubadour, on winning the BBC Radio 2 Lifetime Achievement Award; considers remarkable his career as an itinerant folk musician, creating acoustic hits in 1965 with Catch the Wind and Colours and his version of Buffy Sainte-Marie’s protest anthem, Universal Soldier; notes that he worked with the Beatles, and understands that he influenced Paul McCartney, John Lennon and George Harrison in their guitar styles and that, in his enduring career, he has played with folk music greats including Pete Seeger, Joan Baez and Bob Dylan. Supported by: Jamie Hepburn, Brian Adam, Hugh O’Donnell, Ken Macintosh, Stuart McMillan, Linda Fabiani, Bill Kidd, Rob Gibson, Mike Pringle, Gil Paterson, Robin Harper, Sandra White*, Elaine Smith*
